added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright (C) 2013 Yahoo! Inc. All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # TODO(imelnikov): abstract base class for this import contextlib from taskflow.utils import misc @contextlib.contextmanager def _autobind(task, bind_name, bind_func, **kwargs): try: task.bind(bind_name, bind_func, **kwargs) yield task finally: task.unbind(bind_name, bind_func) def _noop(*args, **kwargs): pass class Executor(object): def execute_task(self, task, arguments, progress_callback=_noop): with _autobind(task, 'update_progress', progress_callback): try: return task.execute(**arguments) except Exception: return misc.Failure() def revert_task(self, task, arguments, result, failures, progress_callback=_noop): kwargs = arguments.copy() kwargs['result'] = result kwargs['flow_failures'] = failures with _autobind(task, 'update_progress', progress_callback): try: return task.revert(**kwargs) except Exception: return misc.Failure()

commit_message:
Storage: use names instead of uuids in interface

Instead of exposing and requiring engines and users to use uuids,
storage now provides more convenient interface that allows to do
anything with task by its name.

Storage is now the entity that maintains name-to-uuid mapping. To
emphasize that, find_by_name method (now unused) was removed from
FlowDetail.

Breaking change: this will break clients that use storage to manipulate
tasks. Clients that use engine.storage only to fetch results with
'fetch' and 'fetch_all' methods (which is the recommended way) are not
affected.

References blueprint task-executor
Co-authored-by: Ivan A. Melnikov <imelnikov@griddynamics.com>
Change-Id: Icbdb745c1ed84c5ac21c6f3a275f32c0b2939d90

commit_message:
Fix sqlalchemy 0.8 issues

Use import of exc instead exception.
Mutability tracking is changed in SQLAlchemy 0.8,
but it seems that sqlalchmy.types.MutableType is not needed
in classes Json and Failure from models.

Closes-bug: 1206669

Change-Id: Ib13c2575ead495b22ed5624e68e044e2f4927201

commit_message:
Enable object caching in cinder REST API requests

Allow the core API to cache resources, such as DB results, so that
extensions can use data already retrieved within the same API request
eliminating additional expensive DB calls.

Loosely based on commit 9f9fbc54e7336da10fc3056bdaca2ec7d01c7f94 from
nova.

Partial-Bug: #1197612
(cherry picked from commit 233430b51ddbd207f22eee98386ffbb766fd777f)

	cinder/tests/api/openstack/test_wsgi.py

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/31/62531/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(Request, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self._resource_cache = {} def cache_resource(self, resource_to_cache, id_attribute='id', name=None): """Cache the given resource. Allow API methods to cache objects, such as results from a DB query, to be used by API extensions within the same API request. The resource_to_cache can be a list or an individual resource, but ultimately resources are cached individually using the given id_attribute. Different resources types might need to be cached during the same request, they can be cached using the name parameter. For example: Controller 1: request.cache_resource(db_volumes, 'volumes') request.cache_resource(db_volume_types, 'types') Controller 2: db_volumes = request.cached_resource('volumes') db_type_1 = request.cached_resource_by_id('1', 'types') If no name is given, a default name will be used for the resource. An instance of this class only lives for the lifetime of a single API request, so there's no need to implement full cache management. """ if not isinstance(resource_to_cache, list): resource_to_cache = [resource_to_cache] if not name: name = self.path cached_resources = self._resource_cache.setdefault(name, {}) for resource in resource_to_cache: cached_resources[resource[id_attribute]] = resource def cached_resource(self, name=None): """Get the cached resources cached under the given resource name. Allow an API extension to get previously stored objects within the same API request. Note that the object data will be slightly stale. :returns: a dict of id_attribute to the resource from the cached resources, an empty map if an empty collection was cached, or None if nothing has been cached yet under this name """ if not name: name = self.path if name not in self._resource_cache: # Nothing has been cached for this key yet return None return self._resource_cache[name] def cached_resource_by_id(self, resource_id, name=None): """Get a resource by ID cached under the given resource name. Allow an API extension to get a previously stored object within the same API request. This is basically a convenience method to lookup by ID on the dictionary of all cached resources. Note that the object data will be slightly stale. :returns: the cached resource or None if the item is not in the cache """ resources = self.cached_resource(name) if not resources: # Nothing has been cached yet for this key yet return None return resources.get(resource_id)

commit_message:
Add support for rebuild --preserve-ephemeral.

This new extension going into Nova permits preserving the ephemeral
partition during a rebuild, getting enough functionality to preserve
state - e.g. on baremetal instances - without Cinder.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ibc4c24bb2efb82c11699231ae76e2755a753a706

commit_message:
Add exception logging if flow creation fails

If the create_XYZ_flow fails in being created
its useful to log exactly what the error was in
detail (instead of trapping it and only raising
a generic error). The more detailed error shows
what the real problem was during the flows
construction (which usually is some larger
problem).

Change-Id: I9cd6b8e2c6298d8791ba3063be78f9b4c4a7c5d0

commit_message:
Don't pass swift headers as None

If we set an header as None for a container swiftclient would just pass
it to httplib which convert it to string and set the None string into
it. This could not be changed in swiftclient to keep backward
compatibility lords happy so make sure that heat doesn't do that.

Closes-Bug: 1259571
Change-Id: Ida1d2cec87e44264f9a7d69a1e220b544b33b63c

commit_message:
clean up invalid_multibyte test

This cleans up the invalid_multibyte test to make it more clear
what it is trying to do, which is send an invalid utf8 sequence as
an image name (it should fail with a 400, it currently passes with
a 202).

Change-Id: I58ad059a138ae96201bbf50df0c22bf259ae9716
Related-Bug: #1006725

commit_message:
ratelimit: different rate for different account

add some features to support individual ratelimit:
1. reseller admin use 'X-Account-Meta-Ratelimit: rate' header
to set new ratelimit on request against /account/container

2. reseller admin use 'X-Container-Meta-Ratelimit-size: rate'
or 'X-Container-Meta-Ratelimit_size: rate' header to set new
ratelimit on request against /account/container/object

others:
fixes some pep9 issue in test/unit/common/middleware/test_ratelimit.py

fixes bug #735173
Change-Id: Icb18717129f189fe4eb8316f322aedd667b66b93

https://review.openstack.org/59489.

1. Alarm in sqlalchemy backend DB requires foreign key contraints to
user_id/project_id. Modified the test cases to honor that.

2. We can't assume the returned items from DB are in a specific sequence
if we haven't provided sorting information to the DB.

Change-Id: Iea7ec4d6388eceba73c9294ddd3b3e437346898d
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed various unit test cases for alarms

Fixed two alarm unit test issues exposed by the patch
https://review.openstack.org/59489.

1. Alarm in sqlalchemy backend DB requires foreign key contraints to
user_id/project_id. Modified the test cases to honor that.

2. We can't assume the returned items from DB are in a specific sequence
if we haven't provided sorting information to the DB.

Change-Id: Iea7ec4d6388eceba73c9294ddd3b3e437346898d

commit_message:
Add policy check for server's delete in v2 api

The policy check added at api layer, that follows bp v3-api-policy.
Use 'compute:' as the scope of policy for keeping consistent with v2 api.
Also provide default policy rule 'rule:admin_or_owner' for delete action.

Partial implements bp v3-api-core-policy

commit_message:
baremetal: cache root images if possible

Previously root images are always fetched from glance for every
instance even if they use the same image. However, when file
injection is disabled (i.e. CONF.baremetal.use_file_injection is
False), the image is not changed on the compute node. So once
fetch the image, we can cache it for later reuse. It reduces the
download time and disk usage of the compute node.

Images are downloaded to a directory managed by imagechache
(e.g. /var/lib/nova/instances/_base/) rather than one for each
instance (e.g. /var/lib/nova/instances/$instance-name/).
A symbolic link is created in the instance directory instead.

Now baremetal.utils.cache_image() needs a lock since it can be
called for the same target path at the same time.

Change-Id: I1c14a9a257f0dc7f1b30956017b11db2aee5474c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/24/59224/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add X-Delete-At parameter test to Swift object expiry test

Add a test of object expiry feature by X-Delete-At HTTP request
header, not just X-Delete-After header.

Note: This test is skipped because of Swift's bug 1069849 by default.
But, this test will be helpful to test present state of object expiry
functions in individual environment.

Change-Id: I647915fcfff606892a4642cc5023d65803d5e8a9
Closes-Bug: #1240829

commit_message:
fix dispatch issue to metadata server update_all

if you make a metadata server update_all requests with no body,
you never actually make it down to metadata server update_all's
update code, as it breaks on a function signature one level up.
This has a nasty side effect of dumping an error in the logs, and
yet returning a 200 to the user (because of where this is caught).

The following fix makes the body parameter have a default value,
thus letting the extension handle the error itself and correctly
return the 400 we are expecting. Added unit testing to ensure that
we don't regress this.

There is also a tempest change waiting in the wings to enforce the
behavior at the tempest layer.

Needed-by: I13a98d93d517a9f6ba9a8bd1e966db30ea2697ad
Fixes-Bug: 1242916

Change-Id: I6ad42c9be0770278a4921045168d9a8afbe6e3c1

commit_message:
Add script for purge db (WIP)

This script implements purging DB from soft_deleted rows, with consideration
of tables relationship.

Change-Id: Ib1c2e87a35d2ce9e2630b6c3a17057719beff6dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/78/57378/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from sqlalchemy.sql import text class DBCleaner(object): def __init__(self, models): """:param models: Module or list of modules with sqlalchemy models.""" self.models = models self.relationship_tree = dict() self.roots = set() self.tables = dict() def _create_tree_from_module(self): """Just another ugly implementation of db relationship tree.""" if type(self.models) is not list: self.models = [self.models] for model in self.models: for module in dir(model): obj = getattr(model, module) if '__tablename__' in dir(obj): ref = obj.__tablename__ self.tables[ref] = obj for prop in dir(obj): try: foreign_keys_set = (getattr(obj, prop). property.columns[0]. foreign_keys) for i in foreign_keys_set: self._add_to_tree(i, prop, ref) except Exception: pass #select roots self.roots = self.relationship_tree.keys() for node in self.relationship_tree: for fk in self.relationship_tree[node]: for child in self.relationship_tree[node][fk]: if child in self.roots: self.roots.remove(child) def _add_to_tree(self, f_key, prop, ref): key, val = f_key.target_fullname.split('.') if key in self.relationship_tree: if val in self.relationship_tree[key]: if ref not in self.relationship_tree[key][val]: self.relationship_tree[key][val][ref] = prop else: self.relationship_tree[key][val] = {ref: prop} else: self.relationship_tree[key] = {val: {ref: prop}} def _purge_node_with_children(self, node, session): if node in self.relationship_tree: for fk in self.relationship_tree[node]: for child in self.relationship_tree[node][fk]: child_col = self.relationship_tree[node][fk][child] rmsg = ("UPDATE {0} " "SET deleted = 1 " "WHERE EXISTS ( " "SELECT * FROM {2} " "WHERE {2}.{3} = {0}.{1} AND " "{2}.deleted != 0)").format(child, child_col, node, fk) session.execute(rmsg) self._purge_node_with_children(child, session) r = text("DELETE FROM %s WHERE deleted != 0;" % node) session.execute(r) def purge_deleted_rows(self, context): @require_admin_context def purge(context): self.ctxt = context self._create_tree_from_module() session = db_session.get_session() with session.begin(): for node in self.roots: self._purge_node_with_children(node, session) purge(context)

commit_message:
Benchmark scenarios for Rally: Nova floating IPs

The patch provides Rally with the basic set of Nova benchmark scenarios for
floating IPs: these include creating/deleting a bunch of floating IPs and
assigning floating IPs to a server.

Blueprint benchmark-scenarios

Change-Id: I783091574b67e9a0e3758ca934e82f8bf48afa3a

commit_message:
Working on models refactoring

Refactor models to use __slots__ for attribute values.
This should have following benefits:
    * reduce overall memory usage
    * allow better field validation

Change-Id: Ie2c371db9a00a0185ed140c21c74d90b1d77ae02
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/85/60885/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import datetime #TODO(Alexei_987) Move all validators to common code (utils?) def validate_date(date): if isinstance(date, datetime.datetime): return date else: raise ValueError('Expected datetime object, received - %s' % date) def validate_object_list(cls): def validator(objects): return all(map(lambda o: isinstance(o, cls), objects)) __slots__ = {} def __init__(self, *args, **attributes): """Constructor that creates on object based on fields described in slots. :param args: positional arguments. Usage of this parameter is discouraged because it depends on the order fields are defined. It's added for backwards compatibility. :param attributes: dict with attribute values """ if args: positional_attrs = dict(zip(self.__slots__, args)) intersects = set(positional_attrs) & set(attributes) if intersects: raise TypeError( _('Got multiple values for arguments - %s') % intersects) attributes.update(positional_attrs) for key, validator in self.__slots__.iteritems(): setattr(self, key, validator(attributes[key])) del attributes[key] if attributes: raise AttributeError( _('Object of type %s doesn\'t support attributes : %s') % ( self.__class__, list(attributes))) for f in self.__slots__: __slots__ = { 'name': str, 'dtype': lambda dtype: int(dtype) if dtype else Trait.NONE_TYPE, 'value': str, }class Event(Model): """A raw event from the source system. Events have Traits. Metrics will be derived from one or more Events. :param message_id: Unique ID for the message this event stemmed from. This is different than the Event ID, which comes from the underlying storage system. :param event_type: The type of the event. :param generated: UTC time for when the event occured. :param traits: list of Traits on this Event. """ __slots__ = { 'message_id': str, 'event_type': str, 'generated': validate_date, 'traits': validate_object_list(Trait), } DUPLICATE = 1 UNKNOWN_PROBLEM = 2 def append_trait(self, trait_model): self.traits.append(trait_model) def __repr__(self): trait_list = [] if self.traits: trait_list = [str(trait) for trait in self.traits] return "<Event: %s, %s, %s, %s>" % \ (self.message_id, self.event_type, self.generated, " ".join(trait_list)) class Meter(Model): """Definition of a meter for which sample data has been collected. :param name: name of the meter :param type: type of the meter (guage, counter) :param unit: unit of the meter :param resource_id: UUID of the resource :param project_id: UUID of project owning the resource :param source: the identifier for the user/project id definition :param user_id: UUID of user owning the resource __slots__ = { 'name': str, 'type': str, 'unit': str, 'resource_id': str, 'project_id': str, 'source': str, 'user_id': str, } class resource :param metadata: most current metadata for the resource (a dict) :param meter: list of the meters reporting data for the resource, """ __slots__ = { 'resource_id': str, 'project_id': str, message_id: a message identifier :param message_signature: a hash created from the rest of the message data """ __slots__ = { 'source': str, 'counter_name': str, 'counter_type': str, 'counter_unit': str, 'counter_volume': str, 'user_id': str, 'project_id': str, 'resource_id': str, 'timestamp': validate_date, 'resource_metadata': str, 'message_id': str, 'message_signature': str, } :param unit: The for the end of the period :param duration: The total time for the matching samples :param duration_start: The earliest time for the matching samples :param duration_end: The latest time for the matching samples :param groupby: The fields used to group the samples. """ __slots__ = { 'unit': str, 'min': str, 'max': str, 'avg': str, 'sum': str, 'count': int, 'period': str, 'period_start': validate_date, 'period_end': validate_date, 'duration': str, 'duration_start': validate_date, 'duration_end': validate_date, 'groupby': str } def validate_alarm_state(state): if state in [ALARM_OK, ALARM_ALARM, ALARM_INSUFFICIENT_DATA]: return state else: raise ValueError(_('Invalid state provided - %s') % state) __slots__ = { 'alarm_id': str, 'type': str, 'enabled': bool, 'name': str, 'description': str, 'timestamp': validate_date, 'user_id': str, 'project_id': str, 'state': validate_alarm_state, 'state_timestamp': validate_date, # TODO(Alexei_987) add validators below 'ok_actions': lambda x: x, 'alarm_actions': lambda x: x, 'insufficient_data_actions': lambda x: x, 'repeat_actions': bool, 'rule': str, } __slots__ = { 'event_id': str, 'alarm_id': str, 'type': str, 'detail': str, 'user_id': str, 'project_id': str, 'on_behalf_of': str, 'timestamp': lambda date: validate_date(date) if date else None, }

commit_message:
VMWare: Enable set_host_enabled for ESXDriver

When runs "nova host-update" with a ESXDriver, nova client will
report exception. This is because of set_host_enabled API need a
return value of host status (enabled or disabled), but ESXDriver
does not return this value.

This patch was enabling ESXDriver return host status when
set_host_enabled was called.

Change-Id: If479c590f7de3027f6c6af4f9cb2c9f0c4380b84
Closes-Bug: #1258767

commit_message:
Replace inheritance hierarchy with composition

In the process of unification of the clients code we should use
composition to allow easier replacement with common HTTPClient.

bp common-client-library-2

Change-Id: I318285e1f0cb55e9d3041b203eee80f90be104ca

commit_message:
Modify tests to run with auth-plugins

Modify tests so that all client tests are run against both the original
client method and the new auth plugins method. There is some scaffolding
introduced to handle the differences between the two methods.

Change-Id: If7e60b72ff309cbd958ea590ff655fcfab1800bb
blueprint: auth-plugins

commit_message:
Enable data locality for HDP plugin

Enabled the savanna data locality features for the HDP plugin.  The
HDP plugin makes use of the topology_helper to create the required
configuration for rack awareness.  This initial implementation assumes
that enabling the feature for the server implies that all clusters
will leverage the capability.

Implementes blueprint hdp-support-data-locality

Change-Id: I12bc5c064baff36c9630a4c48128f97c014fd537

subject: Add member to LBaaS when no servers available always succeed
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-17 13:04:46.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/loadbalancers/workflows.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/859f8cfe7ed2729d1f5c7f36e1fded92b323c86f', 'message': 'Add member to LBaaS when no servers available always succeed

Adding a member to a LBaaS pool when there are no servers
available it shows a "Success: Added member(s)." message.
Also, when there are no servers available, the message says
"Click Add to cancel" which is wrong from the UX perspective.
This patch makes the members field required in order to avoid
succeeding when cero members are added and changes the message
to be more representative.

Change-Id: I5c68b2cc8c5e457aeadee11711d36c802410f08d
Closes-Bug: #1260359
'}]
commit_message:
Add member to LBaaS when no servers available always succeed

Adding a member to a LBaaS pool when there are no servers
available it shows a "Success: Added member(s)." message.
Also, when there are no servers available, the message says
"Click Add to cancel" which is wrong from the UX perspective.
This patch makes the members field required in order to avoid
succeeding when cero members are added and changes the message
to be more representative.

Change-Id: I5c68b2cc8c5e457aeadee11711d36c802410f08d
Closes-Bug: #1260359
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/35/62635/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.fields['members'].label = _( "No servers available. To add a member, you" "need at least one running instance.") self.fields['members'].required = True
deleted_lines: self.fields['members'].label = _("No servers available. " "Click Add to cancel.") self.fields['members'].required = False

Change-Id: I71041be832206e52bfb73926199f2c89e0e84a0b
Closes-Bug: #1260423

commit_message:
Gracefully handle Users with no email attribute

In certain environments, such as when using Keystone with a LDAP
backend, it's possible that the email attribute won't exist for all
users.

Change-Id: I71041be832206e52bfb73926199f2c89e0e84a0b
Closes-Bug: #1260423
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/13/62613/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _update(self, user): email = getattr(user, 'email', '') email=email, 'email': email, def test_update(self): user = self.users.get(id="1") self._update(user) def test_update_with_no_email_attribute(self): user = self.users.get(id="1") del user.email self._update(user)
deleted_lines: def test_update(self): user = self.users.get(id="1") email=u'test@example.com', 'email': user.email,

commit_message:
barematal: Cleanup the calls to assertEqual

Switch the ordering of assertEqual calls to match the correct
(expected, observed) ordering. This makes test failures easier to read.

Change-Id: Iecad55e33be4ab8f7ddff3b4cdbe08aa6c1b8660
Partial-Bug: #1260134

commit_message:
Permit setting the overcloud image update policy.

This is needed to preserve /mnt when rebuilding nodes. In principle we
can do stateful updates with rolling heat stack updates and live
migrations of tenants, cinder data and swift data - but that is a lot
of overhead to use every time - this is just much quicker and is the
path we have agreed on for getting out of the quagmire we're in where
no-one can use us for production image based updates.

Change-Id: I0efa8f52864f49ccdb885f6f655c732c951b3f7a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/26/62526/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This will stop being a parameter once rebuild --preserve-ephemeral is fully # merged. For now, it requires manual effort to use, so it should be opt-in. # Since it's not an end-user thing yet either, we don't document it in the # example prose below either. OVERCLOUD_IMAGE_UPDATE_POLICY=${OVERCLOUD_IMAGE_UPDATE_POLICY:-'REBUILD'} -P "ImageUpdatePolicy=${OVERCLOUD_IMAGE_UPDATE_POLICY}" \

Users can delete it if they want, but updating should be the default,

commit_message:
Preserve the overcloud rather than deleting it.

Users can delete it if they want, but updating should be the default,
because who wants to throw away a cloud on every run!

Change-Id: I3486640fc29d12f5ffdb50d6873dcb8272376ef7

commit_message:
Return 204 when image data does not exist

Currently a GET on image-data in glance v2 returns 404 when data does not
exist. But according to the API docs the HTTP status code returned in this
case should be 204.

This fix makes Glance return the right HTTP status code.

Change-Id: I34cf68e96f631f05cff349329245f74aee42397c
Closes-Bug: #1251055

commit_message:
Add metadata query validation limitation

There is currently no way to pre-determine the schema of
resource_metadata. So it will be hard to validate when
running a query. This patch includes this limitation in
ceilometer documentation.

Change-Id: I804467c3bb8e7d336ae881b25434063839951724
Partial-Bug: #1245367
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/47/61847/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: *metadata.<field>*. Notice, however, that given the free-form nature of *resource_metadata* field, there is not practical nor consistent way to validate the query fields under *metadata* domain like it is done for all other fields. In other words the API call will return HTTP 200 in both scenarios: when a query with *metadata.<field>* does not match its value, and when *<field>* itself does not exist in any of the records being queried.
deleted_lines: *metadata.<field>*.

commit_message:
Remove docker's unsupported capabilities

The 'supports_recreate' flag needs the driver to support the evacuate
operation. The 'has_imagecache' flag needs the driver to implement the
'manage_image_cache' method. Docker does not currently support these
two functions, so the capabilities flags should not be set.

Partial-Bug: #1261636

Change-Id: I191d0d8cd35aece52462c0477f2d89897bb762c1

commit_message:
Serialize instance object while building request_spec

The scheduler utility method for building a request_spec could be passed
an instance dict or instance object.  The jsonutils.to_primitive call on
the request_spec dict serializes an instance object but should not be
relied upon because it uses an interface on the object that may go away.
Instead, an object should be serialized properly before going into the
request_spec.

Change-Id: I9d810a0b8ee6f1beb79d831053f4bbd12b761b0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/62776/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Automatic login after password changed

Currently when a user changed the password successfully,
it will redirect to the login page, the user needs to
input the username and new password to relogin. This will
allow user to automatic login after password changed.

Fixes bug 1252130

Change-Id: I34a8fcda1ef2d93c62c16d5d9a3d5461e9237ee0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/60/56860/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from horizon.utils import functions as utils response = http.HttpResponseRedirect(settings.LOGOUT_URL) msg = _("Password changed. Please log in again to continue.") utils.add_logout_reason(request, response, msg)

commit_message:
Reworks Chassis validations

This makes use of complex types validations of WSME that now works.

Change-Id: I5cd46d5c2caeb3f3c4cd1ef90448e7fd3c81404d
Closes-Bug: #1223847
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/86/57686/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ironic.api.controllers.v1 import types uuid = types.uuid chassis = Chassis(**rpc_chassis.as_dict()) if not expand: chassis.unset_fields(excepting=['uuid', 'description']) else: chassis.links = [link.Link.make_link('self', pecan.request.host_url, 'chassis', chassis.uuid), link.Link.make_link('bookmark', pecan.request.host_url, 'chassis', chassis.uuid) ] @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Chassis, wtypes.text, body=[types.PatchType]) @wsme.validate(wtypes.text, [types.PatchType]) rpc_chassis = objects.Chassis.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, uuid) try: chassis = Chassis(**jsonpatch.apply_patch(rpc_chassis.as_dict(), jsonpatch.JsonPatch(patch))) # Update only the fields that have changed for field in objects.Chassis.fields: if rpc_chassis[field] != getattr(chassis, field): rpc_chassis[field] = getattr(chassis, field) rpc_chassis.save() return Chassis.convert_with_links(rpc_chassis)
deleted_lines: # NOTE: translate 'id' publicly to 'uuid' internally uuid = wtypes.text fields = ['uuid', 'description'] if not expand else None chassis = Chassis.from_rpc_object(rpc_chassis, fields) chassis.links = [link.Link.make_link('self', pecan.request.host_url, 'chassis', chassis.uuid), link.Link.make_link('bookmark', pecan.request.host_url, 'chassis', chassis.uuid) ] if expand: @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Chassis, wtypes.text, body=[wtypes.text]) chassis = objects.Chassis.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, uuid) chassis_dict = chassis.as_dict() utils.validate_patch(patch) try: patched_chassis = jsonpatch.apply_patch(chassis_dict, jsonpatch.JsonPatch(patch)) defaults = objects.Chassis.get_defaults() for key in defaults: # Internal values that shouldn't be part of the patch if key in ['id', 'updated_at', 'created_at']: continue # In case of a remove operation, add the missing fields back # to the document with their default value if key in chassis_dict and key not in patched_chassis: patched_chassis[key] = defaults[key] # Update only the fields that have changed if chassis[key] != patched_chassis[key]: chassis[key] = patched_chassis[key] chassis.save() return Chassis.convert_with_links(chassis)

subject: Do not clone non-raw images in rbd backend
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-27 22:48:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/f147be77991581b9cf83f90fe26c2d8e795cec10', 'message': 'Do not clone non-raw images in rbd backend

RBD backend only supports booting from images in raw format. A volume
that was cloned from an image in any other format is not bootable. The
driver should consider non-raw images to be uncloneable to trigger
automatic conversion to raw format.

Change-Id: I5725d2f7576bc1b3e9b874ba944ad17d33a6e2cb
Closes-Bug: #1246219
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-12-03 17:11:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/db6bb92e7cde78d034fa7e7bac7e64c3061ec81d', 'message': 'Do not clone non-raw images in rbd backend

RBD backend only supports booting from images in raw format. A volume
that was cloned from an image in any other format is not bootable. The

commit_message:
Do not clone non-raw images in rbd backend

RBD backend only supports booting from images in raw format. A volume
that was cloned from an image in any other format is not bootable. The
RBD driver will consider non-raw images to be uncloneable to trigger
automatic conversion to raw format.

Includes conversion of the corresponding unit test to use mock (instead
of mox) and expanded comments and error messages based on change #58893
by Edward Hope-Morley.

Change-Id: I5725d2f7576bc1b3e9b874ba944ad17d33a6e2cb
Closes-Bug: #1246219
Closes-Bug: #1247998

commit_message:
Add OS::Neutron::RouterL3Agent for router.py

This resource supports part of "agent management and scheduler
extensions" in Neutron. It associates router with l3-agent.

see related-bug: #1245366

Closes-bug: #1259845
Change-Id: I781645e62beb4fe60e064d61ad298834e551142d

commit_message:
Fix and enable gating on H402

Summary docstrings should end with punctuation.
Also changed it to command-style in a few places.

Change-Id: Id94fe995aa05356106ad09899b0ada27d608ff21

commit_message:
Stop Neutron advanced service external processes

Some of Neutron advanced services (LBaaS, VPNaaS, ....) creates
external processes and they should be stopped in unstack.
This commit defines neutron_<XaaS>_stop functions for all services
and implements the cleanup logics if necessary.

Also cleanup_neutron removes netns used by LBaaS haproxy.

Change-Id: Ied3a2c374ffcb6b59ecaf1027fb6e6083eded2ae

commit_message:
Match RHEL Beta release strings

RHEL7 (in beta) has "Beta" after the release number and before the
code-name.  Add a number-match to the regex so everything between that
match and the codename in parenthesis is considered the release.

Change-Id: I992f20eedcefc6aeed6bd3ad57fc4cf20c8ef15d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/43/62543/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 7.0 Beta (Maipo) ver=`sed -e 's/^.* \([0-9].*\) (\(.*\)).*$/\1\|\2/' /etc/redhat-release`

commit_message:
Make merge.py installable as a package using pbr

Now that merge.py is invokable from another script
(Ia6b6416fe10358d23f2b120283eecaf4c1178cfd) and from comments at that
review, it makes sense to offer a nicer way to consume the merge
functionality.

Once you git clone tripleo-heat-templates you can python setup.py
install and get /usr/bin/tripleo_heat_merge as well as a
tripleo_heat_merge package in python2.7/site-packages.

Makefile edits required because we moved merge.py into the
tripleo_heat_merge directory for the packaging.

Change-Id: I587fa7a826f93f89e8e5c266af7f5765438fe738
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/23/58823/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Create network-utils element

Creates a new network-utils element which currently contains a
single utility that can be used to create an ovs bridge. This is
being split out from init-neutron-ovs so that it can be used as a
stand alone script in ci.

Change-Id: I8c7bc6bb9db3417811d567a48b6b3a2c628f5ccd

deleted_lines: ovs-vsctl --no-wait -- --may-exist add-br br-int ovs-vsctl --no-wait br-set-external-id br-int bridge-id br-int

commit_message:
Neutron: make logging configurable...

Adds top level neutron.debug and neutron.verbose config parameters
to control Neutron logging.

The motivation for this change is so that we can more easily
control the log level of Neutron. For production our default log
level is still WARN, and for CI we'll be able to easily increase
the level to DEBUG.

Change-Id: I6e02be47db485037fe2a28cb30f0c7253affc20c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/21/62721/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Configuration ------------- neutron: verbose: False - Print more verbose output (set logging level to INFO instead of default WARNING level). debug: False - Print debugging output (set logging level to DEBUG instead of default WARNING level).

commit_message:
Add a diskimage-builder script that creates an Ubuntu 13.04 image.

Implements: blueprint lang-pack-examples

* Work Item: Define a disk image builder template for a base Ubuntu Python 3.3
system - Ubuntu 13.04 includes cloud-init and python 3.3 so no additional
diskimage-builder elements are needed.

Change-Id: Ib785bc7131b4c9d435dee9289e7fcc68509d195a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/76/62476/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # This script requires OpenStack diskimage-builder DIB_RELEASE="raring" disk-image-create --no-tmpfs -a amd64 vm ubuntu -o u1304-py33.qcow2

commit_message:
Make rebuild use Instance objects

This makes the rebuild operation use Instance objects through to
the compute manager. It was already taking them from the rebuild
API code, but converting it to a dict almost immediately, before
it got passed to anything else. This cleans that up and makes it
native.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: I46430af3a52f4fe2f8c2e3c2d654cd8eb0fa1662

commit_message:
Prevent tempest from failing upon ActionInProgress

Jenkins occasionally fails in the 'check-tempest-dsvm-postgres-full'
test.  The tempest tests sometimes try to delete the same stack twice
and an ActionInProgress exception is raised.  This results in ERROR
messages in the log file, which causes the tempest test to fail.

The fix is to decorate the StackLock.acquire method with
client_exceptions, which "allows the declaration of expected exceptions
that the RPC layer should not consider fatal, and not log as if they
were generated in a real error scenario."

Closes-Bug: #1261433
Change-Id: I0692b9d5cf03501ba532b40abf4e567134cda057

deleted_lines: from heat.openstack.common.rpc.common import Timeout except Timeout:

This patch added 2 command line parameters -debug-host and -debug-port
which are used to connect to an external debugger such as pycharm or eclipse.
This feature is used when you want to connect to a nova service via a
debugger running on a different host.  To use it you start the nova service
with --debug-host <where the debugger is running> --debug-port <port it's
listening on>.  This can also be in nova.conf and would go into the DEFAULT
section.  The default is None as you normally do not connect to a debugger
when running in production.

DocImpact
Closes-bug: #1251021
Change-Id: I6ede9bf0813eafbeb91d858c297d4c160aafceba

commit_message:
Enable remote debugging for nova

This patch added 2 command line parameters which are used to
connect to an external debugger such as pycharm or eclipse.
This feature is used when you want to connect to a nova
service via a debugger running on a different host.
To use it you start the nova service with  the following
command line parameters

--remote_debug-host <where the debugger is running>
--remote_debug-port <port> it's listening on>.

DocImpact
Closes-bug: #1251021
Change-Id: I6ede9bf0813eafbeb91d858c297d4c160aafceba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/87/56287/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cli_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('debug-host', default=None, help='Connect to debug host'), cfg.IntOpt('debug-port', default=None, help='Connect to debug host port'), ] CONF.register_cli_opts(cli_opts) if CONF.debug_host and CONF.debug_port: from pydev import pydevd LOG = logging.getLogger('nova.compute') LOG.debug('Listening on %(host)s:%(port)s for debug connection', {'host': CONF.debug_port, 'port': CONF.debug_host}) pydevd.settrace(host=CONF.debug_host, port=CONF.debug_port, stdoutToServer=False, stderrToServer=False)

commit_message:
sysnchronize oslo-incubator modules

Update to get jsonutils compatible with Python 3.

The babel Python module is now required by gettextutils, and gettextutils is
imported by excutils.

Change-Id: Ifa6d6b29e2af58dfcfda1ab7efdb2f32cf9de655

commit_message:
Remove unused oslo-incubator modules

rootwrap and config/generator are more server oriented modules
and for sure unused in a client.

Change-Id: Idc46352fa26a6f4b87ef2ad97d2bd86758c1a0eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/65/62165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines:
#!/usr/bin/env python # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2012 SINA Corporation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: Zhongyue Luo, SINA Corporation. # """Extracts OpenStack config option info from module(s).""" import imp import os import re import socket import sys import textwrap from oslo.config import cfg from ironicclient.openstack.common import gettextutils from ironicclient.openstack.common import importutils gettextutils.install('python-ironicclient') STROPT = "StrOpt" BOOLOPT = "BoolOpt" INTOPT = "IntOpt" FLOATOPT = "FloatOpt" LISTOPT = "ListOpt" MULTISTROPT = "MultiStrOpt" OPT_TYPES = { STROPT: 'string value', BOOLOPT: 'boolean value', INTOPT: 'integer value', FLOATOPT: 'floating point value', LISTOPT: 'list value', MULTISTROPT: 'multi valued', } OPTION_COUNT = 0 OPTION_REGEX = re.compile(r"(%s)" % "|".join([STROPT, BOOLOPT, INTOPT, FLOATOPT, LISTOPT, MULTISTROPT])) PY_EXT = ".py" BASEDIR = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "../../../../")) WORDWRAP_WIDTH = 60 def generate(srcfiles): mods_by_pkg = dict() for filepath in srcfiles: pkg_name = filepath.split(os.sep)[1] mod_str = '.'.join(['.'.join(filepath.split(os.sep)[:-1]), os.path.basename(filepath).split('.')[0]]) mods_by_pkg.setdefault(pkg_name, list()).append(mod_str) # NOTE(lzyeval): place top level modules before packages pkg_names = filter(lambda x: x.endswith(PY_EXT), mods_by_pkg.keys()) pkg_names.sort() ext_names = filter(lambda x: x not in pkg_names, mods_by_pkg.keys()) ext_names.sort() pkg_names.extend(ext_names) # opts_by_group is a mapping of group name to an options list # The options list is a list of (module, options) tuples opts_by_group = {'DEFAULT': []} for pkg_name in pkg_names: mods = mods_by_pkg.get(pkg_name) mods.sort() for mod_str in mods: if mod_str.endswith('.__init__'): mod_str = mod_str[:mod_str.rfind(".")] mod_obj = _import_module(mod_str) if not mod_obj: continue for group, opts in _list_opts(mod_obj): opts_by_group.setdefault(group, []).append((mod_str, opts)) print_group_opts('DEFAULT', opts_by_group.pop('DEFAULT', [])) for group, opts in opts_by_group.items(): print_group_opts(group, opts) print "# Total option count: %d" % OPTION_COUNT def _import_module(mod_str): try: if mod_str.startswith('bin.'): imp.load_source(mod_str[4:], os.path.join('bin', mod_str[4:])) return sys.modules[mod_str[4:]] else: return importutils.import_module(mod_str) except ImportError as ie: sys.stderr.write("%s
" % str(ie)) return None except Exception: return None def _is_in_group(opt, group): "Check if opt is in group." for key, value in group._opts.items(): if value['opt'] == opt: return True return False def _guess_groups(opt, mod_obj): # is it in the DEFAULT group? if _is_in_group(opt, cfg.CONF): return 'DEFAULT' # what other groups is it in? for key, value in cfg.CONF.items(): if isinstance(value, cfg.CONF.GroupAttr): if _is_in_group(opt, value._group): return value._group.name raise RuntimeError( "Unable to find group for option %s, " "maybe it's defined twice in the same group?" % opt.name ) def _list_opts(obj): def is_opt(o): return (isinstance(o, cfg.Opt) and not isinstance(o, cfg.SubCommandOpt)) opts = list() for attr_str in dir(obj): attr_obj = getattr(obj, attr_str) if is_opt(attr_obj): opts.append(attr_obj) elif (isinstance(attr_obj, list) and all(map(lambda x: is_opt(x), attr_obj))): opts.extend(attr_obj) ret = {} for opt in opts: ret.setdefault(_guess_groups(opt, obj), []).append(opt) return ret.items() def print_group_opts(group, opts_by_module): print "[%s]" % group print global OPTION_COUNT for mod, opts in opts_by_module: OPTION_COUNT += len(opts) print '#' print '# Options defined in %s' % mod print '#' print for opt in opts: _print_opt(opt) print def _get_my_ip(): try: csock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_DGRAM) csock.connect(('8.8.8.8', 80)) (addr, port) = csock.getsockname() csock.close() return addr except socket.error: return None def _sanitize_default(s): """Set up a reasonably sensible default for pybasedir, my_ip and host.""" if s.startswith(BASEDIR): return s.replace(BASEDIR, '/usr/lib/python/site-packages') elif BASEDIR in s: return s.replace(BASEDIR, '') elif s == _get_my_ip(): return '10.0.0.1' elif s == socket.gethostname(): return 'python-ironicclient' elif s.strip() != s: return '"%s"' % s return s def _print_opt(opt): opt_name, opt_default, opt_help = opt.dest, opt.default, opt.help if not opt_help: sys.stderr.write('WARNING: "%s" is missing help string.
' % opt_name) opt_type = None try: opt_type = OPTION_REGEX.search(str(type(opt))).group(0) except (ValueError, AttributeError) as err: sys.stderr.write("%s
" % str(err)) sys.exit(1) opt_help += ' (' + OPT_TYPES[opt_type] + ')' print '#', "
# ".join(textwrap.wrap(opt_help, WORDWRAP_WIDTH)) try: if opt_default is None: print '#%s=<None>' % opt_name elif opt_type == STROPT: assert(isinstance(opt_default, basestring)) print '#%s=%s' % (opt_name, _sanitize_default(opt_default)) elif opt_type == BOOLOPT: assert(isinstance(opt_default, bool)) print '#%s=%s' % (opt_name, str(opt_default).lower()) elif opt_type == INTOPT: assert(isinstance(opt_default, int) and not isinstance(opt_default, bool)) print '#%s=%s' % (opt_name, opt_default) elif opt_type == FLOATOPT: assert(isinstance(opt_default, float)) print '#%s=%s' % (opt_name, opt_default) elif opt_type == LISTOPT: assert(isinstance(opt_default, list)) print '#%s=%s' % (opt_name, ','.join(opt_default)) elif opt_type == MULTISTROPT: assert(isinstance(opt_default, list)) if not opt_default: opt_default = [''] for default in opt_default: print '#%s=%s' % (opt_name, default) print except Exception: sys.stderr.write('Error in option "%s"
' % opt_name) sys.exit(1) def main(): if len(sys.argv) < 2: print "usage: %s [srcfile]...
" % sys.argv[0] sys.exit(0) generate(sys.argv[1:]) if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
Rename nodes/<uuid>/state to nodes/<uuid>/states

The commit https://review.openstack.org/#/c/60299 refactored the /state
subresource of nodes in the Ironic API and one of the changes made was
to rename the subresource from /state to /states (plural) since now both
power and provision state can be retrieved in one request call.

Change-Id: I3e3cf29fa0fd48063ae0ca14eac6f685ccc44e65
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/58/60558/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: '/v1/nodes/%s/states/power' % NODE1['uuid']: ('PUT', '/v1/nodes/%s/states/power' % NODE1['uuid'], {}, body),
deleted_lines: '/v1/nodes/%s/state/power' % NODE1['uuid']: ('PUT', '/v1/nodes/%s/state/power' % NODE1['uuid'], {}, body),

subject: Change "Jar" job type to "MapReduce"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-13 18:41:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara/commit/811488a435b4fd71c6221938814f756e914fff8f', 'message': 'Change "Jar" job type to "MapReduce"

Changes the "Jar" job type to "MapReduce".  This maps more closely
to the underlying Oozie actions, and will help remove ambiguity when
Savanna supports Oozie "java" actions in the future.

Backward compatibility is supported as follows:
1) Any job created through the REST api with job type "Jar" will
have its job type automatically changed to "MapReduce"

2) Attempts to run jobs in an existing Savanna database that have
a job type of "Jar" will be allowed.

3) Attempts to retrieve config hints for job type "Jar" will return
the config hints for "MapReduce"

These measures should allow this change to work with a UI which is
still using the "Jar" job type.

Closes-Bug #1260829

Change-Id: I1ad59fa466b9a5d838c62bf366b642e453340bce
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-12-16 22:15:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara/commit/5a811aa9858e24029a4f580ca42f442d05cbb78d', 'message': 'Change "Jar" job type to "MapReduce"

Changes the "Jar" job type to "MapReduce".  This maps more closely
to the underlying Oozie actions, and will help remove ambiguity when
Savanna supports Oozie "java" actions in the future.

Backward compatibility is supported as follows:
1) Any job created through the conductor with job type "Jar" will
have its job type automatically changed to "MapReduce"

2) Tests for job_type "Jar" have been changed to test for membership
in ["Jar", "MapReduce"]. This should support existing jobs in a
savanna database with type "Jar", even though all new jobs will be

commit_message:
Change "Jar" job type to "MapReduce"

Changes the "Jar" job type to "MapReduce".  This maps more closely
to the underlying Oozie actions, and will help remove ambiguity when
Savanna supports Oozie "java" actions in the future.

Backward compatibility is supported as follows:
1) Any job created through the conductor with job type "Jar" will
have its job type automatically changed to "MapReduce"

2) Tests for job_type "Jar" have been changed to test for membership
in ["Jar", "MapReduce"]. This should support existing jobs in a
savanna database with type "Jar", even though all new jobs will be
"MapReduce"

These measures should allow this change to work with a UI which is
still using the "Jar" job type.

Closes-Bug: #1260829

Change-Id: I1ad59fa466b9a5d838c62bf366b642e453340bce

deleted_lines: res = w_f.get_possible_job_config("Jar")

commit_message:
Fix syntax of relative imports for Python3

In Python 3, relative imports must be written "from .module import name":
http://docs.python.org/3.0/whatsnew/3.0.html#removed-syntax

Change-Id: I2ec8a7330e63ea64d291f2f37f0c01cdf765d4f7

deleted_lines: from client import * from dispatcher import * from server import *

commit_message:
Add Sample priority

With the routing notifier we can now issue high-frequency notifications
and not worry about clogging up the queue. The Sample priority will
be used for this situation.

Change-Id: Ia4aa77b7aa4ca9458e97ca3ed81101d92934b691

commit_message:
Remove eventlet related code in amqp driver

Because driver should rely on executor and not directly on eventlet,
delete eventlet related code. This also drop the old driver API.

This is the amqp part.

Change-Id: Ic6060058dafa4dabbc5e8c68bf231c818a7fec25
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/16/62416/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: import inspectimport sysfrom eventlet import greenpoolclass _ThreadPoolWithWait(object): """Base class for a delayed invocation manager. Used by the Connection class to start up green threads to handle incoming messages. """ def __init__(self, conf, connection_pool): self.pool = greenpool.GreenPool(conf.rpc_thread_pool_size) self.connection_pool = connection_pool self.conf = conf def wait(self): """Wait for all callback threads to exit.""" self.pool.waitall() class CallbackWrapper(_ThreadPoolWithWait): """Wraps a straight callback. Allows it to be invoked in a green thread. """ def __init__(self, conf, callback, connection_pool): """Initiates CallbackWrapper object. :param conf: cfg.CONF instance :param callback: a callable (probably a function) :param connection_pool: connection pool as returned by get_connection_pool() """ super(CallbackWrapper, self).__init__( conf=conf, connection_pool=connection_pool, ) self.callback = callback def __call__(self, message_data): self.pool.spawn_n(self.callback, message_data) class ProxyCallback(_ThreadPoolWithWait): """Calls methods on a proxy object based on method and args.""" def __init__(self, conf, proxy, connection_pool): super(ProxyCallback, self).__init__( conf=conf, connection_pool=connection_pool, ) self.proxy = proxy self.msg_id_cache = _MsgIdCache() def __call__(self, message_data): """Consumer callback to call a method on a proxy object. Parses the message for validity and fires off a thread to call the proxy object method. Message data should be a dictionary with two keys: method: string representing the method to call args: dictionary of arg: value Example: {'method': 'echo', 'args': {'value': 42}} """ # It is important to clear the context here, because at this point # the previous context is stored in local.store.context #if hasattr(local.store, 'context'): # del local.store.context rpc_common._safe_log(LOG.debug, _('received %s'), message_data) self.msg_id_cache.check_duplicate_message(message_data) ctxt = unpack_context(self.conf, message_data) method = message_data.get('method') args = message_data.get('args', {}) version = message_data.get('version') namespace = message_data.get('namespace') if not method: LOG.warn(_('no method for message: %s') % message_data) ctxt.reply(_('No method for message: %s') % message_data, connection_pool=self.connection_pool) return self.pool.spawn_n(self._process_data, ctxt, version, method, namespace, args) def _process_data(self, ctxt, version, method, namespace, args): """Process a message in a new thread. If the proxy object we have has a dispatch method (see rpc.dispatcher.RpcDispatcher), pass it the version, method, and args and let it dispatch as appropriate. If not, use the old behavior of magically calling the specified method on the proxy we have here. """ ctxt.update_store() try: rval = self.proxy.dispatch(ctxt, version, method, namespace, **args) # Check if the result was a generator if inspect.isgenerator(rval): for x in rval: ctxt.reply(x, None, connection_pool=self.connection_pool) else: ctxt.reply(rval, None, connection_pool=self.connection_pool) # This final None tells multicall that it is done. ctxt.reply(ending=True, connection_pool=self.connection_pool) except rpc_common.ClientException as e: LOG.debug(_('Expected exception during message handling (%s)') % e._exc_info[1]) ctxt.reply(None, e._exc_info, connection_pool=self.connection_pool, log_failure=False) except Exception: # sys.exc_info() is deleted by LOG.exception(). exc_info = sys.exc_info() LOG.error(_('Exception during message handling'), exc_info=exc_info) ctxt.reply(None, exc_info, connection_pool=self.connection_pool)

commit_message:
Change IgnoreAttemptedHostFilter to expect 'retry' key

The newly added IgnoreAttemptedHostFilter is renamed from RetryFilter, but
there's also a change in the key it expected in filter_properties ('retry'->
'attempted').  This change actually breaks backwards compatibility if it's
been used in an environment where old/new scheduler worked together and old
scheduler processed the request prior new scheduler (old scheduler that uses
RetryFilter will add 'retry' key to filter_properties).  This kind of
situation can happen in a rolling upgrade in a multi-scheduler deployment and
should be fixed.

Change-Id: I0da5092833190f7e6dadfaaacfa4545e85d45a15
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/03/61003/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: to the 'retry' key of filter_properties in order for this to work correctly. For example: { 'retry': { 'hosts': ['host1', 'host2'], 'num_attempts': 2, } } attempted = filter_properties.get('retry', None) LOG.debug(_("Re-scheduling is disabled."))
deleted_lines: to the 'attempted' key of filter_properties in order for this to work correctly. attempted = filter_properties.get('attempted', None) LOG.debug(_("Re-scheduling is disabled"))

commit_message:
Refactored access to RequestContext

RequestContext is passed all over the internal api and it's only used in
few places in oslo code and some ironic drivers.
I've refactored access to context to make it directly available using:
ironic.common.context.get_current_context() function
This allows us to remove context parameter from everywhere.

Review process suggestions:
1) ironic/common/context.py - This file provides basic functionality and
you need to check it to get the main idea
2) ironic/api/hooks.py - This is a entry point that publishes context
for all public API requests
3) ironic/conductor/manager.py - Entry point that publishes context for
internal tasks run by scheduler
4) Review all other files. In most files we just remove context from
parameters. In test files we fix mock assertions and setUp to publish
context manually

Change-Id: Ibe4ac3dcef430cdafca3d4785ae5fc45fd4b7751

commit_message:
Fix a lazy-load exception in security_group_update()

When security_group_api is nova, the update_security_group api raises http
500 error: group rules fails with lazy load exception. Because the rule
infos of the security group will be return in response body, but the rule
attribute hasn't been preloaded.

Closes-Bug: #1244018
Change-Id: Ie07879ac22e4add90f75968778bf334915e8349c

commit_message:
Fix a bug in safe_encode where it returns a bytes object in py3

Used the six module to dynamically determine python version
and decode the returned bytes object to a string if python3 is
being used

Change-Id: I9e46199e86cba63f530eaef47e53f0de170bdd94
Closes-Bug: #1249995

added_lines: if six.PY3: return text.encode(encoding, errors).decode(incoming) else: return text.encode(encoding, errors) if six.PY3: return text.encode(encoding, errors).decode(incoming) else: return text.encode(encoding, errors)
deleted_lines: return text.encode(encoding, errors) return text.encode(encoding, errors)

commit_message:
Notifier Proxy

Proxy for making notification calls in manner safe for conversion to
oslo.messaging.

Change-Id: I046f0f5383ecec7d95e1a253d5abc125350fed95
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/08/60308/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Proxy openstack.common.notifier.api.notify() to look like an oslo.messaging.notify Driver""" class NotifierProxy(object): def __init__(self, notifier_api, publisher_id): self.notifier_api = notifier_api self.publisher_id = publisher_id def audit(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): # No audit in old notifier. self.notifier_api.notify(ctxt, self.publisher_id, event_type, payload, 'INFO') def debug(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self.notifier_api.notify(ctxt, self.publisher_id, event_type, payload, 'DEBUG') def info(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self.notifier_api.notify(ctxt, self.publisher_id, event_type, payload, 'INFO') def warn(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self.notifier_api.notify(ctxt, self.publisher_id, event_type, payload, 'WARN') warning = warn def error(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self.notifier_api.notify(ctxt, self.publisher_id, event_type, payload, 'ERROR') def critical(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self.notifier_api.notify(ctxt, self.publisher_id, event_type, payload, 'CRITICAL')

subject: Remove keystone from default_log_levels default
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-13 17:22:37.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/common/log.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/fe18bfa4c19d6a18cf922a40af37b327b68e3aed', 'message': 'Remove keystone from default_log_levels default

"keystone=INFO" was in the default_log_levels. This made it
more difficult than necessary to debug the Keystone server,
since you can set debug=True but then the keystone logging
level is overridden and you get no debug output for keystone.

"keystone=INFO" may have been in the default_log_levels because
of the auth_token middleware, but this has been moved to
python-keystoneclient now and the logging config for the
python APIs is done differently.

Closes-Bug: 1245629

Change-Id: Ifc4187188f2be2fc876893e9b75e062f0dfcce97
'}]
commit_message:
Remove keystone from default_log_levels default

"keystone=INFO" was in the default_log_levels. This made it
more difficult than necessary to debug the Keystone server,
since you can set debug=True but then the keystone logging
level is overridden and you get no debug output for keystone.

"keystone=INFO" may have been in the default_log_levels because
of the auth_token middleware, but this has been moved to
python-keystoneclient now and the logging config for the
python APIs is done differently.

Closes-Bug: 1245629

Change-Id: Ifc4187188f2be2fc876893e9b75e062f0dfcce97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/48/62048/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

added_lines: import commandsimport sysfrom tempest.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def _can_ping(self, ip, command="ping"): """Attempt to ping the specified IP, and give up after 1 second.""" # NOTE(devcamcar): ping timeout flag is different in OSX. if sys.platform == 'darwin': timeout_flag = 't' else: timeout_flag = 'w' self.LOG.debug('trying to ping - %s' % ip) status, output = commands.getstatusoutput('%s -c1 -%s1 %s' % (command, timeout_flag, ip)) return status == 0 if self._can_ping(self.host): self.LOG.debug('trying to ssh - %s' % self.host) ssh.connect(self.host, username=self.username, password=self.password, look_for_keys=self.look_for_keys, key_filename=self.key_filename, timeout=self.channel_timeout, pkey=self.pkey) _timeout = False break except socket.error as exc: self.LOG.exception(exc) except paramiko.AuthenticationException as exc: self.LOG.exception(exc) except paramiko.SSHException as exc: self.LOG.exception(exc) except Exception as exc: self.LOG.exception(exc) time.sleep(bsleep) bsleep *= backoff
deleted_lines: ssh.connect(self.host, username=self.username, password=self.password, look_for_keys=self.look_for_keys, key_filename=self.key_filename, timeout=self.channel_timeout, pkey=self.pkey) _timeout = False break except (socket.error, paramiko.AuthenticationException, paramiko.SSHException): time.sleep(bsleep) bsleep *= backoff continue

Change-Id: Ia4ce1ea618116fa51e847e1bbb9b804ab4c32870
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1261158
(cherry picked from commit 9683b13fad4b892daaefd16422eb31f10ea951e3)
'}]
commit_message:
Added clarity for installing Neutron plugin on dedicated controller

As reported to Launchpad, the instructions for setting up the Neutron
server on a dedicated controller that will NOT be providing any
underlying functionality are not clear as to why we need to install
and configure the plugin here.

Change-Id: Ia4ce1ea618116fa51e847e1bbb9b804ab4c32870
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1261158
(cherry picked from commit 9683b13fad4b892daaefd16422eb31f10ea951e3)

commit_message:
Refactor PXE DHCP Option support.

The previous support imported pxe into driver, but driver is meant to
be entirely decoupled from specific baremetal drivers.

Co-Authored-By: Robert Collins <rbtcollins@hp.com>

Change-Id: Icc7c40fe06b520aa220906122f5f6be8d79a3ac4

commit_message:
Update autogenerate-config-docs for openstack-doc-tools

Let's keep the flagmappings as part of openstack-manuals and the
tool itself in openstack-doc-tools.

This patch removes the tools and updated the documentation.
A corresponding patch for openstack-doc-tools will be done.

Change-Id: Iad8f0607af9ff8522e6d7567cfa685301813ecfe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/65/62465/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines:
#!/usr/bin/env python import sys from os import path import glob from xml.dom import minidom from xml.sax.saxutils import escape #Swift configuration example files live in # swift/etc/*.conf-sample # and contain sections enclosed in [], with # options one per line containing = # and generally only having a single entry # after the equals (the default value) def parse_line(line): """ takes a line from a swift sample configuration file and attempts to separate the lines with actual configuration option and default value from the rest. Returns None if the line doesn't appear to contain a valid configuration option = default value pair, and a pair of the config and its default if it does. """ if '=' not in line: return None temp_line = line.strip('#').strip() config, default = temp_line.split('=', 1) config = config.strip() if ' ' in config and config[0:3] != 'set': if len(default.split()) > 1 or config[0].isupper(): return None if len(config) < 2 or '.' in config or '<' in config or '>' in config: return None return config, default.strip() def get_existing_options(optfiles): """ parses an existing XML table to compile a list of existing options """ options = {} for optfile in optfiles: xmldoc = minidom.parse(optfile) tbody = xmldoc.getElementsByTagName('tbody')[0] trlist = tbody.getElementsByTagName('tr') for tr in trlist: try: optentry = tr.childNodes[1].childNodes[0] option, default = optentry.nodeValue.split('=', 1) helptext = tr.childNodes[2].childNodes[0].nodeValue except IndexError: continue if option not in options or 'No help text' in options[option]: #options[option.split('=',1)[0]] = helptext options[option] = helptext return options def extract_descriptions_from_devref(repo, options): """ loop through the devref RST files, looking for lines formatted such that they might contain a description of a particular option """ option_descs = {} rsts = glob.glob(repo + '/doc/source/*.rst') for rst in rsts: rst_file = open(rst, 'r') in_option_block = False prev_option = None for line in rst_file: if 'Option ' in line: in_option_block = True if in_option_block: if '========' in line: in_option_block = False continue if line[0] == ' ' and prev_option is not None: option_descs[prev_option] = (option_descs[prev_option] + ' ' + line.strip()) for option in options: line_parts = line.strip().split(None, 2) if (' ' in line and len(line_parts) == 3 and option == line_parts[0] and line_parts[1] != '=' and option != 'use' and (option not in option_descs or len(option_descs[option]) < len(line_parts[2]))): option_descs[option] = line_parts[2] prev_option = option return option_descs def new_section_file(sample, current_section): section_filename = ('swift-' + path.basename(sample).split('.conf')[0] + '-' + current_section.replace('[', '').replace(']', '').replace(':', '-') + '.xml') section_file = open(section_filename, 'w') section_file.write(' \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ ') return section_file def create_new_tables(repo, verbose): """ writes a set of docbook-formatted tables, one per section in swift configuration files. Uses existing tables and swift devref as a source of truth in that order to determine helptext for options found in sample config files """ existing_tables = glob.glob('../../doc/common/tables/swift*xml') options = {} #use the existing tables to get a list of option names options = get_existing_options(existing_tables) option_descs = extract_descriptions_from_devref(repo, options) conf_samples = glob.glob(repo + '/etc/*conf-sample') for sample in conf_samples: current_section = None section_file = None sample_file = open(sample, 'r') for line in sample_file: if '[' in line and '] ' in line and '=' not in line: """ it's a header line in the conf file, open a new table file for this section and close any existing one """ if current_section != line.strip('#').strip(): if section_file is not None: section_file.write(' \
Description of configuration options for ' + current_section + ' in ' + path.basename(sample) + '
Configuration option=Default valueDescription
\ ') section_file.close() current_section = line.strip('#').strip() section_file = new_section_file(sample, current_section) elif section_file is not None: """ it's a config option line in the conf file, find out the help text and write to the table file. """ parsed_line = parse_line(line) if parsed_line is not None: if (parsed_line[0] in options.keys() and 'No help text' not in options[parsed_line[0]]): # use the help text from existing tables option_desc = options[parsed_line[0]].replace(u'\xa0', u' ') elif parsed_line[0] in option_descs: # use the help text from the devref option_desc = option_descs[parsed_line[0]].replace(u'\xa0', u' ') else: option_desc = 'No help text available for this option' if verbose > 0: print parsed_line[0] + "has no help text" section_file.write(' \ ' + parsed_line[0] + '=' + escape(str(parsed_line[1])) + '' + option_desc + ' ' + ' ') if section_file is not None: section_file.write(' \ \ ') section_file.close() def main(repo, verbose=0): """ writes a set of docbook-formatted files, based on configuration sections in swift sample configuration files """ create_new_tables(repo, verbose) if __name__ == "__main__": main(sys.argv[1])

commit_message:
Added note for Cinder Controller requirements

Although intended, the Cinder Controller document does not make it
clear as to why the 'cinder-volume' service is not installed. The
guide assumes that multiple nodes are being used; one to run all
of the controller services and many other service nodes to provide
functionality. In this case, the second part of the document
provides instructions on how to complete the process. This patch
adds a node, enhancing the first paragraph to make it clearer.

Change-Id: I0c640f5e4fca438edf214bfe00480938294c3245
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1260338
(cherry picked from commit 46ba7f31b6f381f877c2bea3f85d9a29170dd1c7)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/67/62667/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <note> <para>This section details the configuration of OpenStack Block Storage services on the <emphasis>Controller</emphasis> node. The guide assumes that a second node will be used to present storage via the <systemitem class="service">cinder-volume</systemitem> service.</para> <para> See <xref linkend="cinder-node"/> for instructions on configuring the second node. </para> </note>
deleted_lines: <para>To create the components that control the Block Storage Service, complete the following steps on the controller node.</para>

commit_message:
Remove flagmappings

flagmappings stay as data in openstack-manuals, see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/62465/.

Remove them and update the README.

Change-Id: Ie6453f9e5e2a30f7a41bd20bdffd82b8a001e6bc

commit_message:
Rework repository to make it an installable python package

This is an overhaul of the complete content to make it
a separate python package that can be installed on the jenkins
machines as well as on editor's machines.

The goal of this patchset is to package everything
and get the command "openstack-doc-test" running so that
it can be used for gating.

This will need further refinement for the other commands.

Change-Id: Icc2f1807dd5ab5fb2f83c05d1b3895b3a9a0dbaf

subject: Create Savanna user for Keystone
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-17 13:38:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/8876bc9e9f0283c926c5e9899d3458c2afaeb488', 'message': 'Create Savanna user for Keystone

commit_message:
Clarified location of driver config settings; removed ESX driver reference; minor text edits.

UPDATED part 3: Build failed! fixed program listing tags
UPDATED part 2: Build failed. Checked and modified tag formatting.
UPDATED: Removed tabs and applied correct use of <filename> tags.

* Clarified details of volume driver configuration settings for VMDK drivers in nova.conf and cinder.conf.

* Removed reference to ESX/ESXi server driver config because it has not been extensively tested.

* Changed occurrences of "data store" to "datastore" for consistency.

Change-Id: I2a45b131fa19749530f5fe93115518f8b9f4ea4e
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1260005
(cherry picked from commit abd25235ac3ea7c39b5899e536c7bf98321a3e1e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/70/61670/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Storage volumes on vCenter-managed datastores. Volumes are backed by VMDK files on datastores using any VMware the VMware vCenter VMDK driver. When configuring the driver, you must match it with the drivers must point to the same server. For example, in the nova.conf file, the volume driver setting is: volume_driver=vmwareapi.VMwareVCDriver In the cinder.conf file, the volume driver setting is: volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.vmware.vmdk.VMwareVcVmdkDriver drivers support for the OpenStack Block Storage configuration (cinder.conf): file type is specified using the vmware:vmdk_type extra spec key with the Datastore selection When creating a volume, the driver chooses a datastore on a datastore that is selected using the strategy
deleted_lines:
Storage volumes on vCenter managed data stores. Volumes are backed by VMDK files on data stores using any VMware the VMware vCenter VMDK driver. An ESX VMDK driver is provided as well, but it has not been extensively tested. When configuring either driver, you must match it with the drivers must point to the same server. The following table captures this configuration mapping:
Cinder-Nova configuration mapping with VMware server
VMware Server OpenStack Compute Driver OpenStack Block Storage Driver
vCenter server vmwareapi.VMwareVCDriver cinder.volume.drivers.vmware.vmdk.VMwareVcVmdkDriver
ESX/ESXi server vmwareapi.VMwareESXDriver cinder.volume.drivers.vmware.vmdk.VMwareEsxVmdkDriver
drivers support: file type is specified using the vmware:vmdk_type extra spec key with the Data store selection When creating a volume, the driver chooses a data store on a data store that is selected using the strategy

commit_message:
Allocate separate journal partitions for each OSD

Change-Id: Ie9cde42620ba8f63d4ef3f8b36786a9a49317e83
Closes-bug: #1260546
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/97/62497/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import math def get_partition_count(self, name): count = 0 for disk in self.iterdisks(): count += len([v for v in disk["volumes"] if v.get('name') == name and v['size'] > 0]) return count def num_ceph_journals(self): return self.get_partition_count('cephjournal') def num_ceph_osds(self): return self.get_partition_count('ceph') ceph_osds = self.num_ceph_osds() journals_left = ceph_osds ceph_journals = self.num_ceph_journals() if part.get('name') == 'cephjournal': # We need to allocate a partition for each ceph OSD # If there is more than one journal device the journals # will be divided evenly amongst them. No more than 10GB # will be allocated to a single journal partition. ratio = math.ceil(float(ceph_osds) / ceph_journals) size = part["size"] / ratio size = size if size <= 10240 else 10240 end = ratio if ratio < journals_left else journals_left for i in range(0, end): journals_left -= 1 pcount = self.pcount(disk["id"], 1) self.pre("parted -a none -s /dev/{0} " "unit {4} mkpart {1} {2} {3}".format( disk["id"], self._parttype(pcount), self.psize(disk["id"]), self.psize(disk["id"], size * self.factor), self.unit)) self.post("chroot /mnt/sysimage sgdisk " "--typecode={0}:{1} /dev/{2}".format( pcount, part["partition_guid"],disk["id"])) continue def get_partition_count(self, name): count = 0 for disk in self.iterdisks(): count += len([v for v in disk["volumes"] if v.get('name') == name and v['size'] > 0]) return count def num_ceph_journals(self): return self.get_partition_count('cephjournal') def num_ceph_osds(self): return self.get_partition_count('ceph') ceph_osds = self.num_ceph_osds() journals_left = ceph_osds ceph_journals = self.num_ceph_journals() if part.get('name') == 'cephjournal': # We need to allocate a partition for each ceph OSD # If there is more than one journal device the journals # will be divided evenly amongst them. No more than 10GB # will be allocated to a single journal partition. ratio = math.ceil(float(ceph_osds) / ceph_journals) size = part["size"] / ratio size = size if size <= 10240 else 10240 end = ratio if ratio < journals_left else journals_left for i in range(0, end): journals_left -= 1 pcount = self.pcount('/dev/%s' % disk["id"], 1) self.late("parted -a none -s /dev/{0} " "unit {4} mkpart {1} {2} {3}".format( disk["id"], self._parttype(pcount), self.psize('/dev/%s' % disk["id"]), self.psize('/dev/%s' % disk["id"], size * self.factor), self.unit)) self.late("sgdisk --typecode={0}:{1} /dev/{2}" "".format(pcount, part["partition_guid"], disk["id"]), True) continue

commit_message:
Display message on HTTP 400

This patch parses the faultstring given by the server on 400 errors if
available.

Change-Id: Ieae2f0b39fed2c45f276d6c931bebfebab9f696e
Closes-Bug: bug #1260394
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ceilometerclient refs/changes/12/62412/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 eNovance # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json from ceilometerclient import exc from ceilometerclient.tests import utils class HTTPBadRequestTest(utils.BaseTestCase): def test_str_no_details(self): exception = exc.HTTPBadRequest() self.assertEqual("HTTPBadRequest (HTTP 400)", str(exception)) def test_str_no_json(self): exception = exc.HTTPBadRequest(details="foo") self.assertEqual("HTTPBadRequest (HTTP 400)", str(exception)) def test_str_no_error_message(self): exception = exc.HTTPBadRequest(details=json.dumps({})) self.assertEqual("HTTPBadRequest (HTTP 400)", str(exception)) def test_str_no_faultstring(self): exception = exc.HTTPBadRequest( details=json.dumps({"error_message": {"foo": "bar"}})) self.assertEqual("HTTPBadRequest (HTTP 400)", str(exception)) def test_str_error_message_unknown_format(self): exception = exc.HTTPBadRequest( details=json.dumps({"error_message": "oops"})) self.assertEqual("HTTPBadRequest (HTTP 400)", str(exception)) def test_str_faultstring(self): exception = exc.HTTPBadRequest( details=json.dumps({"error_message": {"faultstring": "oops"}})) self.assertEqual("HTTPBadRequest (HTTP 400) ERROR oops", str(exception))

subject: Clarify rebuild_instance's recreate parameter.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-06 03:15:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/129d90ce5888e456805bebf9b69c231bd2f56685', 'message': "Clarify rebuild_instance's recreate parameter.

As far as I can tell this parameter actually implies that none of the
cleanup happens - it's used when evacuating an instance to a separate
hypervisor, so the new hypervisor has rebuild(recreate=True) passed
in. The docstring didn't make that clear, so this trivial patch
hopefully does that.
